p: In general, as salinity was reduced, successful larval settlement also significantly decreased. This was observed in previous studies on Acropora hyacinthus, Favites abdita, Platygyra daedalea and P. sinensis, where successful settlement of larvae decreased with reduced salinity from 32 psu ambient to 28 psu [ 49]. However, no effect of reduced salinity (36 psu ambient to 28 psu) on settlement was reported in Orbicella faceolata [ 38]. These variable susceptibilities of corals to salinity stress could be related to different tolerances of coral species [ 50]. Moreover, it is plausible that local ambient conditions to which the parent colonies are exposed may also influence the response of their offspring [ 50â€“ 51]. These corals may be in different states of acclimatization and adaptation to salinity stresses, particularly in regions that are frequently exposed to low salinity.
